# Complete Guide

> For execution instructions, see [SKILL.md](../SKILL.md)

# Partnership Development Playbook

## Overview

Strategic partnerships can 10x your reach without 10x-ing your team. This skill teaches solo entrepreneurs and small teams how to identify, develop, and scale high-value partnerships that drive mutual growth through co-marketing, joint solutions, and ecosystem leverage.

**The Partnership Multiplier:**
```
Your Reach: 1,000 customers
Partner's Reach: 10,000 customers
Joint Campaign: Potential 11,000 combined audience
Cost: $0 (vs. $50K+ to acquire 10K customers via ads)

ROI: Infinite (leverage vs. cash)
```

---

## When to Use This Skill

- You want to expand reach without hiring a sales team
- Your product complements other tools/services
- You're targeting the same customers as adjacent companies
- You need credibility in a new market (co-sell with trusted brand)
- Your growth is bottlenecked by distribution, not product
- You're exploring channel partnerships or resellers
- You want to build an ecosystem around your product

---

## Why Partnerships Matter for Solo Entrepreneurs

**The Leverage Equation:**
```
Traditional Growth:
Revenue = (Team Size × Productivity) × Efficiency
Growth requires hiring (expensive, slow)

Partnership Growth:
Revenue = (Your Resources + Partner Resources) × Alignment
Growth requires coordination (cheap, fast)

Example:
Solo founder:
- $5K/month marketing budget
- 1,000 email subscribers
- 20 new customers/month

With 3 partnerships:
- $5K + Partner budgets ($30K combined)
- 1,000 + 50,000 combined subscribers
- 20 + 60 new customers/month (from partner referrals)

Result: 4x growth, same team size
```

**When Partnerships Beat Solo Efforts:**
- **Distribution Access:** Partner has your target audience
- **Credibility Transfer:** Partner's brand validates yours
- **Cost Efficiency:** Shared marketing costs, split CAC
- **Speed to Market:** Leverage partner's sales team
- **Product Gaps:** Fill feature gaps with integrations

---

## Partnership Types & When to Use Each

### 1. Co-Marketing Partnerships

**What it is:** Joint marketing campaigns that promote both companies

**Best for:**
- Expanding email list and brand awareness
- Launching new products
- Entering new markets

**Examples:**
- Co-host webinar: "How [Your Tool] + [Partner Tool] = 10x Results"
- Joint ebook: "[Industry] Playbook by [You] & [Partner]"
- Cross-promotion: Feature each other in newsletters

**Ideal partner profile:**
- Same target audience, different solution
- Similar company size/stage (avoid huge disparities)
- Non-competitive but complementary

**ROI:**
```
Co-Marketing Campaign Example:
Your email list: 2,000
Partner's list: 8,000
Combined webinar: 10,000 invites

Attendance: 1,000 (10% conversion)
New leads: 500 (50% new to you)
New customers: 25 (5% conversion at $100/month)

Value: $2,500 MRR = $30K ARR
Cost: 10 hours of your time
ROI: $3,000/hour
```

---

### 2. Integration Partnerships

**What it is:** Technical product integrations that add value to both tools

**Best for:**
- Increasing product stickiness
- Reducing churn (harder to leave if integrated)
- Expanding use cases

**Examples:**
- API integration (e.g., CRM ↔ Email Tool)
- Native integration in partner's app marketplace
- Zapier/Make.com connection

**Ideal partner profile:**
- Popular tool your customers already use
- Strong developer platform/API
- Active marketplace with integration directory

**ROI:**
```
Integration Impact:
Customers with integration: 40% churn
Customers without: 20% churn
Churn reduction: 50%

100 customers at $50/month:
Without integration: Lose 40/year = -$24K ARR
With integration: Lose 20/year = -$12K ARR
Value saved: $12K ARR per 100 customers

Build cost: 40 hours ($4K if outsourced)
Payback: <2 months
```

---

### 3. Referral/Affiliate Partnerships

**What it is:** Partners refer customers in exchange for commission or reciprocal referrals

**Best for:**
- Scaling sales without hiring reps
- Incentivizing word-of-mouth
- Channel sales (agencies, consultants)

**Examples:**
- Affiliate program: 20% recurring commission
- Reciprocal referrals: You send them customers, they send you customers
- Agency partnerships: White-label or resell your product

**Ideal partner profile:**
- Has direct relationship with your target customers
- Trusted advisor (consultant, agency, influencer)
- Incentive-aligned (earns more when you succeed)

**Commission Structures:**
```
One-time referral: $500 per closed deal
Recurring: 20% of MRR for 12 months
Lifetime: 10% of all revenue from referred customer
Tiered: 10% (1-5 referrals), 15% (6-10), 20% (11+)

Example Agency Partnership:
Agency has 50 clients (your ICP)
Converts 20% to your product: 10 new customers
Avg deal: $200/month = $2K MRR
Agency commission (20%): $400/month
Your net: $1,600 MRR = $19.2K ARR

CAC via agency: $0 upfront, $4,800/year in commissions
vs. Traditional CAC: $2,000 upfront per customer
Winner: Agency partnership (cash flow + scalability)
```

---

### 4. Co-Selling Partnerships

**What it is:** Joint sales efforts where both companies sell together

**Best for:**
- Enterprise deals (complex, multi-stakeholder)
- Selling into same accounts
- Bundled solutions

**Examples:**
- Bundle pricing: "Buy both tools, save 20%"
- Joint proposals: Pitch combined solution together
- Strategic account mapping: Share target account lists

**Ideal partner profile:**
- Sells to same decision-maker
- Complementary solution (solves adjacent pain)
- Similar deal size and sales cycle

**ROI:**
```
Solo Enterprise Deal:
Win rate: 20% (hard to get meetings, perceived as risky)
Avg deal: $50K
Pipeline: 10 opps = 2 wins = $100K

With Co-Selling Partner:
Win rate: 40% (warm intro, reduced risk via bundle)
Avg deal: $75K ($50K + $25K partner)
Your share: $50K
Pipeline: 10 opps = 4 wins = $200K

Lift: 2x revenue, same effort
```

---

## Partner Identification Framework

### Step 1: Define Your Ideal Partner Profile (IPP)

**Criteria to consider:**
```
□ Target Audience Overlap: >70% of their customers = your ICP
□ Non-Competitive: Different product category
□ Complementary: Solves related problem (before/after yours in workflow)
□ Similar Stage: Company size within 2x of yours (avoid misaligned resources)
□ Shared Values: Culture fit, customer-first mindset
□ Engagement History: Responsive, professional, reliable
```

**Example IPP:**
```
Your Company: Email marketing automation for e-commerce
Ideal Partner: E-commerce platforms (Shopify, WooCommerce)

Why ideal:
✓ 100% audience overlap (all e-commerce brands)
✓ Non-competitive (platform vs. marketing tool)
✓ Complementary (store needs email marketing)
✓ Integration opportunity (API available)
✓ Large partner ecosystem (marketplace, app directory)
```

---

### Step 2: Partner Discovery & Research

**Where to find partners:**

**1. Your customers' tool stack**
- Survey: "What other tools do you use daily?"
- CRM data: Check email domains, integrations used
- Community: Ask in Slack/Discord what people love

**2. Integration marketplaces**
- Zapier (see what tools connect to yours)
- App directories (Salesforce AppExchange, HubSpot Marketplace, Shopify App Store)
- G2/Capterra (filter by category, check "integrates with" section)

**3. Content & social**
- LinkedIn: Search "[your category] + [related category]"
- Industry reports: "Best [category] tools 2024"
- Podcasts/webinars: Who's speaking at same events?

**4. Competitive research**
- Check competitors' partner pages
- See who they integrate with
- Identify gaps you can fill

**Partner Research Template:**
```
Partner Name: _________________
Website: _________________
Company Size: _____ employees
Target Market: _________________
Product/Service: _________________
Overlap Score (1-10): _____
Complementary Score (1-10): _____
Reach (email list, traffic, customers): _________________
Partnership Opportunity: □ Co-marketing □ Integration □ Referral □ Co-selling
Priority: □ Tier 1 (Strategic) □ Tier 2 (Tactical) □ Tier 3 (Opportunistic)
```

---

### Step 3: Partner Tiering

**Tier 1: Strategic Partners (Top 3-5)**
- Massive reach or strategic importance
- Long-term relationship potential
- Significant resource investment justified
- Executive-level relationships
- Formal partnership agreements

**Tier 2: Tactical Partners (10-20)**
- Moderate reach, specific use case
- Project-based collaboration
- Mid-level relationships (marketing/sales)
- Lightweight agreements

**Tier 3: Opportunistic Partners (50+)**
- Small reach, low effort
- One-off collaborations
- No formal agreement needed
- Network building

**Allocation of Resources:**
```
Tier 1: 60% of partnership time
Tier 2: 30% of partnership time
Tier 3: 10% of partnership time

Example Time Allocation (10 hours/week):
- Tier 1 (3 partners): 6 hours = 2 hours each
- Tier 2 (15 partners): 3 hours = 12 min each
- Tier 3 (50 partners): 1 hour = ~1 min each (newsletters, quick touches)
```

---

## Partnership Outreach & Pitching

### The Partnership Pitch Formula

**Template:**
```
Subject: [Quick Win] Partnership idea for [Their Company]

Hi [Name],

I'm [Your Name], founder of [Your Company]. We help [target customer] achieve [outcome].

I noticed that:
1. [Specific observation about their company/product]
2. [Evidence of audience overlap or complementary solution]

I think there's a quick win opportunity:
[Specific partnership idea - be concrete]

Example:
"Co-host a webinar on '[Topic Their Audience Cares About]' to both our audiences (combined 15K reach). We'd handle production, you bring expertise."

What it gets us both:
- You: [Benefit to them - be specific with numbers]
- Us: [Benefit to you - show it's mutual]

15-minute call to explore?

[Your Name]
[Title]
[Contact]

P.S. [Social proof - mutual connection, customer overlap, or credibility builder]
```

**Good example:**
```
Subject: Co-marketing idea: Email Marketing x E-commerce

Hi Sarah,

I'm Tom, founder of EmailBoost. We help e-commerce brands recover abandoned carts via automated emails.

I noticed your Shopify app has 10K installs – our customers overlap 100% (all e-commerce).

Quick win idea:
Co-author "The Complete Guide to E-commerce Email" ebook. You cover store optimization, we cover email campaigns. Promote to both our audiences (combined 20K subscribers).

What it gets us:
- You: 1,000+ new leads (our email list), content for your blog
- Us: 5,000+ new leads (your audience), Shopify store credibility

30-min call next week?

Tom
Founder, EmailBoost
tom@emailboost.com

P.S. We have 15 mutual customers who use both our tools daily (see attached list).
```

**Bad example (vague, one-sided):**
```
Subject: Partnership Opportunity

Hi,

We'd love to partner with you. Let me know if you're interested!

Thanks
```

---

### Outreach Channels

**Ranked by effectiveness:**

1. **Warm intro (95% response rate)**
   - Mutual customer: "Hey [Partner], [Customer] suggested we talk – they use both our tools"
   - Mutual connection: "Hey [Partner], [Investor/Advisor] thought we'd be a great fit"
   - Existing relationship: Met at conference, interacted on Twitter

2. **Personalized email (30% response rate)**
   - Use template above
   - Reference specific content (podcast, blog post, product feature)
   - Show you've done research

3. **LinkedIn DM (20% response rate)**
   - Connect first, wait 2 days, then message
   - Shorter version of email pitch

4. **Cold email (5% response rate)**
   - Last resort
   - Must be extremely relevant and valuable

**Follow-up cadence:**
```
Day 0: Initial outreach
Day 3: Follow-up #1 (add new value - "Saw your recent blog post on X, relevant to our idea")
Day 7: Follow-up #2 (Social proof - "Just closed a similar partnership with [Company]")
Day 14: Final follow-up (Breakup email - "Should I assume this isn't a priority? Happy to reconnect later")

Stop after 3 follow-ups. Move to Tier 3 (passive nurture).
```

---

## Co-Marketing Campaign Execution

### Campaign Types

**1. Co-Hosted Webinar**

**Template:**
```
Topic: "[Outcome] with [Your Tool] + [Partner Tool]"
Example: "10x Your E-commerce Revenue with Shopify + EmailBoost"

Format:
- 45 minutes content (20 min you, 20 min partner, 5 min Q&A)
- Recorded for on-demand viewing
- Joint promotional landing page

Promotion (50/50 split):
- Email: 3 emails each (2 weeks before, 1 week before, day of)
- Social: 5 posts each (LinkedIn, Twitter)
- Retargeting: Pixel both audiences

Landing page elements:
- Joint branding (both logos prominent)
- Speaker bios with credibility builders
- Clear CTA: Register with email
- Social proof: "[X] people registered"

Post-webinar:
- Share recording with both lists
- Email attendees: "Thanks for joining! Here's the recording + resources"
- Nurture: 3-email sequence to non-attendees

Metrics to track:
- Registrations (by source: your list vs. theirs)
- Attendance rate (benchmark: 40-50%)
- Leads generated (new emails captured)
- Opportunities created (demo requests, trials)
- Revenue attributed (closed deals)
```

**Expected ROI:**
```
Webinar Investment:
Your time: 10 hours (planning, content, promotion)
Partner time: 10 hours
Tools: $0 (Zoom free, or Livestorm $100/month)

Webinar Results:
Registrations: 500 (250 yours, 250 partner's)
Attendance: 200 (40% show rate)
New leads: 125 (50% new to you)
Trials: 25 (20% conversion)
Customers: 5 (20% trial→paid)

Revenue: 5 × $100/month = $500 MRR = $6K ARR
ROI: $6K / 10 hours = $600/hour
```

---

**2. Joint Content (Ebook, Guide, Report)**

**Template:**
```
Title: "The Ultimate [Topic] Guide by [Your Company] + [Partner]"
Example: "The SaaS Growth Playbook by ProductHunt + Amplitude"

Format:
- 20-30 pages PDF
- Your expertise: Chapters 1-3
- Partner expertise: Chapters 4-6
- Joint intro/conclusion

Content breakdown:
- Problem statement (collaborative)
- Your solution + case study (your part)
- Partner solution + case study (their part)
- Combined approach: "Best of both" (collaborative)
- Resource checklist (both tools mentioned)

Promotion:
- Gated landing page (email required to download)
- Email drip: 5-email sequence over 2 weeks
- Social: 10 posts per company over 30 days
- Paid: Optional - $500 LinkedIn/Facebook ads each

Content repurposing:
- Blog series: 1 chapter = 1 blog post (6 posts total)
- Social snippets: Quote graphics from ebook
- Email course: 7-day email course based on ebook
```

**Expected ROI:**
```
Ebook Investment:
Your time: 20 hours (writing, editing, design)
Partner time: 20 hours
Design: $500 (or Canva $0)

Ebook Results:
Downloads: 1,000 (500 yours, 500 theirs)
Email subscribers: 1,000
Trials: 50 (5% conversion)
Customers: 10 (20% trial→paid)

Revenue: 10 × $100/month = $1K MRR = $12K ARR
ROI: $12K / 20 hours = $600/hour
```

---

**3. Cross-Promotion (Newsletter, Blog, Social)**

**Template:**
```
Format: Feature partner in your content, they feature you in theirs

Your newsletter mention:
- Subject: "Tool Spotlight: How [Partner] Helps [Outcome]"
- 200-word blurb about partner
- CTA: "Try [Partner] free" (affiliate link optional)
- Placement: After main content, before footer

Partner's newsletter mention:
- Mirror format for your tool

Frequency: Monthly or quarterly

Terms:
- Equal prominence (both above the fold or both in secondary position)
- No payment (barter deal)
- Track clicks via UTM links (utm_source=partner_newsletter)
```

**Expected ROI:**
```
Cross-Promotion Investment:
Your time: 2 hours (write blurb, coordinate)
Partner time: 2 hours

Results (per mention):
Newsletter reach: 5,000 (partner's list size)
Click-through: 100 (2% CTR)
Trials: 10 (10% conversion)
Customers: 2 (20% trial→paid)

Revenue: 2 × $100/month = $200 MRR = $2.4K ARR
ROI: $2.4K / 2 hours = $1,200/hour
```

---

## Joint Solution Development

### Integration Design

**Step 1: Identify integration use case**
```
Question: What workflow does the integration enable?

Bad answer: "Our tools work well together"
Good answer: "When a customer completes checkout in Shopify (Partner), automatically add them to EmailBoost (Us) and send welcome sequence"

Integration value prop:
- Saves time: Manual CSV export/import → Automatic sync
- Prevents errors: No data entry mistakes
- Enables workflow: Trigger-based actions (event → action)
```

**Step 2: Scope integration MVP**
```
Scoping Framework:
1. One-way vs. two-way sync?
   - One-way: Shopify → EmailBoost (easier, MVP)
   - Two-way: Shopify ↔ EmailBoost (complex, v2)

2. Which data fields?
   - MVP: Email, name, purchase date (critical fields only)
   - V2: Add tags, segments, order value

3. Trigger frequency?
   - Real-time: Event happens → instant sync (best UX, complex)
   - Batch: Sync every hour/day (easier, delayed)

4. Error handling?
   - MVP: Email admin if sync fails
   - V2: Retry logic, detailed error logs

5. Authentication?
   - OAuth (secure, user-friendly, complex to build)
   - API key (simpler, less secure)
```

**Step 3: Build & test**
```
Build Options:
1. Native integration (you build directly)
   - Cost: $5-10K (40-80 hours dev time)
   - Control: Full
   - Discovery: Listed in partner's marketplace

2. Zapier/Make integration
   - Cost: $0-500 (8-16 hours to set up triggers/actions)
   - Control: Limited to Zapier's capabilities
   - Discovery: Zapier app directory

3. Partner builds (you provide API docs)
   - Cost: $0 (partner invests dev time)
   - Control: None (dependent on partner prioritization)
   - Discovery: Best (partner promotes their own work)

Testing checklist:
□ Happy path: Integration works for standard use case
□ Error handling: What happens if API fails, data is malformed, auth expires?
□ Performance: Can it handle 1K syncs/hour? 10K?
□ User experience: Clear setup instructions, helpful error messages
□ Security: API keys encrypted, OAuth tokens refreshed
```

**Expected ROI:**
```
Integration Development:
Cost: $5K (native) or $500 (Zapier)
Time: 2 months to launch

Impact (Year 1):
Customers using integration: 100 (out of 1,000 total customers)
Churn reduction: 50% → 25% for integrated customers
Customers saved: 25 (would have churned without integration)

Revenue saved: 25 × $100/month × 12 = $30K ARR
ROI: $30K / $5K = 6x

Plus:
- Marketplace listing: 500 new signups/year
- Partner referrals: 200 customers/year
- Product stickiness: Higher expansion revenue from integrated customers
```

---

## Partner Revenue Attribution

### Tracking Partner-Sourced Customers

**UTM Tagging System:**
```
URL structure:
https://yoursite.com/?utm_source=partner_name&utm_medium=partnership&utm_campaign=webinar_2024

Parameters:
- utm_source: partner_name (unique per partner)
- utm_medium: partnership (consistent across all partners)
- utm_campaign: specific_initiative (webinar, ebook, newsletter)

Example:
Partner: Shopify
Campaign: Co-hosted webinar on email marketing
URL: yoursite.com/?utm_source=shopify&utm_medium=partnership&utm_campaign=email_webinar_nov2024

Track in:
- Google Analytics: Source/Medium report
- CRM: Create "Partner Source" field, populate via form or API
```

**CRM Tracking:**
```
Lead Fields to Capture:
□ Partner Source (dropdown: Shopify, WooCommerce, etc.)
□ Partnership Campaign (text: webinar_nov2024, ebook_growth)
□ Partner Contact Date (date)
□ Partner Status (checkbox: Active, Inactive)

Deal/Opportunity Fields:
□ Partner Attributed (checkbox: Yes/No)
□ Partner Name (lookup: links to Partner record)
□ Partner Commission (currency: $200)
```

**Attribution Report Template:**
```
Partner Performance Dashboard:

Partner | Leads | Opps | Customers | Revenue | Commission | ROI
Shopify | 500 | 50 | 10 | $12K ARR | $2.4K | 5x
WooCommerce | 300 | 30 | 8 | $9.6K ARR | $1.9K | 5x
BigCommerce | 100 | 10 | 2 | $2.4K ARR | $480 | 5x

Totals | 900 | 90 | 20 | $24K ARR | $4.8K | 5x

ROI Calculation:
Revenue: $24K ARR
Costs: $4.8K (commissions) + $2K (time investment) = $6.8K
Net: $17.2K
ROI: 253%
```

---

## Ecosystem Mapping

### Building Your Partner Network

**Ecosystem Map Template:**
```
Your Product: [Your Company]
Category: [Your Category]

Tier 1: Strategic Partners (Direct Integration)
┌─────────────┐
│  Partner A  │ ← Primary integration, co-selling
└─────────────┘

Tier 2: Tactical Partners (Co-Marketing)
┌────────────┐  ┌────────────┐  ┌────────────┐
│ Partner B  │  │ Partner C  │  │ Partner D  │
└────────────┘  └────────────┘  └────────────┘
      ↓               ↓               ↓
  Referrals    Content Swaps    Webinars

Tier 3: Ecosystem (Indirect)
┌────┐ ┌────┐ ┌────┐ ┌────┐ ┌────┐
│ E  │ │ F  │ │ G  │ │ H  │ │ I  │
└────┘ └────┘ └────┘ └────┘ └────┘
Newsletter mentions, social shares, loose affiliations
```

**Network Effects:**
```
As your partner network grows:

1 partner → 1x reach
5 partners → 5x reach
10 partners → 15x reach (partners cross-promote each other)
20 partners → 50x reach (ecosystem effects)

Example:
You promote Partner A → Partner A's audience discovers Partner B → Partner B promotes you → New audience discovers you via B

This compounding effect makes partnerships exponentially valuable.
```

---

## Common Partnership Mistakes

### ❌ Mistake #1: One-Sided Partnerships

**Problem:** You pitch what you get, not what partner gets
**Example:** "Partner with us to get access to our 1K customers!" (but partner has 100K customers – no incentive)

**Fix:** Lead with partner value
- "Your 100K customers need [solution you provide]. We'll create custom content for your audience, driving engagement and retention."
- Show metrics: "Partners see 25% lift in engagement when they offer integrated solutions"

---

### ❌ Mistake #2: No Clear Agreement

**Problem:** Vague handshake deal → misaligned expectations → partnership fails

**Fix:** Document partnership terms
```
Partnership Agreement (Simple):

Partners: [Your Company] & [Partner Company]
Type: Co-marketing partnership
Duration: 6 months (renewable)

Commitments:
- [Your Company] will: Host quarterly webinar, promote Partner in newsletter (monthly)
- [Partner Company] will: Co-host webinar, promote You in newsletter (monthly)

Success Metrics:
- 1,000 combined webinar registrations per quarter
- 500 new leads for each company
- 10 new customers for each company (attributed to partnership)

Review Cadence: Monthly check-in (30 min)
Exit Clause: Either party can exit with 30 days notice

Signatures:
_________________   _________________
[Your Name]         [Partner Name]
```

---

### ❌ Mistake #3: Too Many Partners, Too Little Focus

**Problem:** 50 partners, all Tier 3, no real impact

**Fix:** Tier and focus
- 80% effort on Top 3 partners
- 20% effort on next 10
- Automate/ignore the rest until they prove value

---

### ❌ Mistake #4: No Attribution Tracking

**Problem:** Can't prove partnership ROI → can't justify continued investment

**Fix:** Track everything
- UTM links for all partner campaigns
- CRM field: "Partner Source"
- Monthly report: Partner-attributed revenue

---

## Partnership Success Metrics

**Track monthly:**
```
Input Metrics (Activities):
□ New partners contacted: ____ (goal: 10/month)
□ Partnership calls held: ____ (goal: 5/month)
□ Active partnerships: ____ (goal: 10 total)

Output Metrics (Results):
□ Partner-attributed leads: ____ (goal: 100/month)
□ Partner-attributed customers: ____ (goal: 5/month)
□ Partner-attributed revenue: $____ ARR (goal: $10K/month)

Efficiency Metrics:
□ Cost per partner lead: $____ (goal: <$5)
□ Partner lead→customer rate: ___% (goal: >5%)
□ Avg revenue per partnership: $____ (goal: >$5K ARR)
```

**Partnership Health Score:**
```
Score each active partnership (0-100):

Engagement (40 points):
- Responsive to outreach: 10 pts
- Joins regular check-ins: 10 pts
- Proactive with ideas: 10 pts
- Delivers on commitments: 10 pts

Results (40 points):
- Leads generated: 10 pts (>10/quarter)
- Customers generated: 20 pts (>2/quarter)
- Revenue impact: 10 pts (>$1K ARR)

Strategic Fit (20 points):
- Audience overlap: 10 pts (>70%)
- Brand alignment: 5 pts
- Long-term potential: 5 pts

Rating:
80-100: Tier 1 (Strategic) - Invest heavily
60-79: Tier 2 (Tactical) - Maintain
40-59: Tier 3 (Watch list) - Reduce effort
<40: Sunset partnership
```

---

## Partnership Development Checklist

**Phase 1: Discovery (Week 1-2)**
- [ ] Define Ideal Partner Profile (IPP)
- [ ] Identify 20 potential partners via research
- [ ] Tier partners (T1: 3, T2: 7, T3: 10)
- [ ] Create outreach list with contact info

**Phase 2: Outreach (Week 3-4)**
- [ ] Send personalized outreach to all 20
- [ ] Follow up 3x per partner (days 3, 7, 14)
- [ ] Schedule calls with interested partners
- [ ] Present partnership pitch (clear value prop)

**Phase 3: Agreement (Week 5-6)**
- [ ] Define partnership type and scope
- [ ] Set success metrics and goals
- [ ] Document commitments in simple agreement
- [ ] Assign owners (who does what by when)

**Phase 4: Execution (Ongoing)**
- [ ] Launch partnership campaign (webinar, ebook, etc.)
- [ ] Track results via UTM links and CRM
- [ ] Monthly check-in with partner (30 min)
- [ ] Quarterly business review (1 hour)

**Phase 5: Optimization (Quarterly)**
- [ ] Review partnership performance vs. goals
- [ ] Double down on top performers (increase investment)
- [ ] Sunset low performers (reduce to Tier 3 or end)
- [ ] Identify new partnership opportunities

---

## Partnership Development ROI

**Time Investment:**
```
Setup: 20 hours (research, outreach, agreements)
Ongoing: 10 hours/month (campaign execution, check-ins)

Annual: 140 hours
```

**Impact:**
```
Before Partnerships:
- Growth: 10 new customers/month (organic only)
- CAC: $500 (paid ads)
- ARR growth: $60K/year

After Partnerships (3 active partnerships):
- Growth: 10 organic + 15 partner-referred = 25/month
- Blended CAC: $200 (partner CAC = $0 upfront)
- ARR growth: $150K/year

Value created: $90K additional ARR
Time invested: 140 hours
ROI: $642/hour
```
